avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow fell in SE winds this week. Minor snowfall then fell in northerly winds followed rain in the mountains on Thursday. The snowpack has melted considerably and gotten stronger but small unstable wind slabs as well as cornices could be present in gullies and depressions.

snowpackStructure.highlights: Snow melted considerably on Thursday in a rainy weather in the mountains followed by minor snowfall early on Friday. New snow could bind poorly with older snow and small wind slabs or cornices could form around terrain traps. Older snow is widely considered stable and cohesive after several melt-freeze cycles in recent weeks. This had less effect higher in the mountains and unstable wind slabs or cornices have likely grown there in various aspects.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in NE-N winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high. Weak layers have been detected in the snowpack and it could a few days for the snowpack to develop and settle. Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.
travelAdvisory.highlights: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in NE-N winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high.

weatherForecast.highlights: Lítilsháttar éljabakkar mögulegir á Sunnudag en annars úrkomulaust að mestu um helgina. Vindur norðanstæður 10-15 m/sek til fjalla en lægir með helginni. Hiti sveiflast um helgina frá -6 til 2 gráðum en það kólnar eftir helgi.

avalancheActivity.comment: Several avalanches fell in the region after a N-NE blizzard at the end of the week. Multiple slab avalanches were also reported on Monday and Tuesday 18.3. and 19.3. The largest was size 3 in Dýrafjörður.
avalancheActivity.highlights: N and NE snowstorm passed the region in the last days and natural avalanches have widely fallen. A lot of snow has drifted into SE - NW aspects but the snowpack is unstable in all aspects.

snowpackStructure.highlights: Last week, snow was added in E and NE wind and again in two consecutive NE blizzards this week. Unstable wind slabs formed and multiple avalanches released in the area. Snow pits from the region confirm the presence of unstable wind slabs with stiff melt-freeze snow beneath. Weak layers have been detected within the new snow but also between the new snow and the older snow. Several avalanches fell in the region after the first storm this week and also on Friday after the second storm. The wind slabs in SE - NW aspects have grown considerably and are unstable. People should avoid steep terrain while the snowpack is adjusting after the storm.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in NE-N winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high. Weak layers have been detected in the snowpack and it could a few days for the snowpack to develop and settle. Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.

weatherForecast.highlights: NA og N hríðarveður gekk yfir svæðið seinnipart föstudags eftir mikla snjókomu og skafrenning. Lægir með helginni og úrkomulaust að mestu. Frost 8-12 stig til fjalla.

avalancheActivity.comment: Several slab avalanches have occurred in the area in recent days. An avalanche released on the road to Kleifar in Ólafsfjörður and out into the sea on Friday morning. Two major avalanches fell on the road from Dalvík to Ólafsfjörður night before Saturday. Additionally, an avalanche fell on the road to Siglufjörður west of the Strákagöng tunnel. Two size 3 and 3.5 avalanches released above Dalvík on the night to Saturday. Avalanches of size 2-3.5 occurred in Ólafsfjörður, specifically in Arnfinnsfjall, Ósbrekkufjall, Auðnahyrna, and Bustabrekkudal, likely releasing night before Saturday or Friday
avalancheActivity.highlights: It has snowed a lot in the area since Thursday. It can be expected that the new snow will remain unstable over the weekend, with thick wind drifts found in most aspects, especially southern aspects. Human triggered avalanches are likely to occur.

snowpackStructure.highlights: A strong N wind and significant snowfall has persisted in the area since Thursday and continues until mid-Saturday. Thick wind drifts have likely formed widely, especially on southern aspects due to the wind. It can be expected that the new snow will be unstable at first over the weekend. Several avalanches have occurred in the area in recent days and natural avalanches can be expected while the weather persists. The underlying snow is considered fairly stable, although some weaknesses may still be present. As the weekend approaches, people heading to the mountains should proceed with caution and adhere to good travel practices. Note that the snow pack is likely unstable for a while and human triggered avalanches are likely to release.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in NE-N winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high. Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.

weatherForecast.highlights: Lægir seinnipart laugardags og lítilsháttar él yfir nóttina. Hægur vindur og él til fjalla á sunnudag. Rólegt veður á mánudag, úrkomulítið og birtir til.

avalancheActivity.comment: Several avalanches occurred in the area during the week, including slab avalanches caused by snowmobilers in Fannardalur on March 20th, natural slab avalanches from Norðfjörður on March 19th, and in Eskifjörður on March 15th.
avalancheActivity.highlights: A considerable amount of snow has fallen in the northern slopes during snowfall since Friday. Unstable wind slabs could be present on most aspects, but there is little snow in the lower part of the mountains, so wind slabs are primarily found at higher elevations.

snowpackStructure.highlights: Thick wind slabs are present on southern aspects following a northerly winds on Friday and Saturday. They are expected to be unstable initially. Last week, wind slabs formed in northerly directions, resulting in a somewhat layered snowpack, with the possibility of weaknesses at layer interfaces. The underlying layers are considered fairly stable, and there is little snow in the lower parts of the mountains due to recent thawing.

travelAdvisory.comment: The snowpack is currently very unstable in the Westfjords and Tröllaskagi regions. A blizzard passed the regions in NE-N winds on Thursday and Friday and avalanche danger is high. Weak layers have been detected in the snowpack and it could a few days for the snowpack to develop and settle. Many natural slab avalanches have been falling in both regions and people traveling in the mountains should practice caution and avoid steep hills.

weatherForecast.highlights: Norðvestanátt og éljagangur til fjalla á sunnudag og áfram á mánudag.
